div.p: 011-015, Field Naturalists Club of Victoria, Melbourne.

From your letter of yesterday,
Letter not found. dear Mr Best, I learn, that the Field-Naturalists Club intends to bestow on me the honor of nominating me to the Presidency for the ensuing year. This mark of high consideration I appreciate all the more, as I have so little claim on this great distinction by any active participation in the work of the Club since its formation. But though I fully recognize the generous feelings, which prompted the members, to offer so distinguished a position to me, I feel, that I ought not to add to my responsibilities at all events during the next twelve months. Only recently I have finished a new volume of mine, of which I beg to submit herewith a copy to the Club;
B83.13.07? while issuing this extensive literary production, much other work had to be deferred, and this weighs all the more heavily on me, as I have neither the facilities nor the auxiliaries of former years for my scientific efforts. Thus I am conscious, that I could but poorly respond to the obligations, which with the presidential office of the Club would devolve on me, and I therefore beg of the Gentlemen, who so kindly wish me to undertake leading functions in their union, to withdraw my name from the Candidature at present. If however Providence grants me life and strength somewhat longer, I will be happy to act in a presidential capacity for a year after the present,
See M to D. Best, 8 March 1884. whereby you will see, that I do not undervalue the confidence, which by the intended trust is placed in me.
